meta.project: DC Garden Tracker – Master Agronomy JSON

last_frost_assumption.description: Average last 32°F frost date (midpoint of typical window)

first_frost_assumption.description: Average first 32°F frost date (midpoint of typical window)

how_to_use: Use plants[].task_plan to generate a unified 'what to do now' queue.
Use task_templates to standardize actions across crops.
Use amendments_library for dosage normalization and safety checks.
If your last/first frost differs, update meta.region.* and regenerate dates using offsets.

primary_use: general fertility for vegetables, herbs, containers

garden_bed_preplant.rate: Follow label; common organic granular baseline is ~3–5 lb per 100 sq ft worked into top few inches
garden_bed_preplant.frequency: pre-plant, then top-dress every 6–8 weeks for heavy feeders

container_topdress.rate: Follow label; typical topdress is 1–2 Tbsp per gallon of potting mix surface area equivalent

compatibility_notes: Do not over-apply with additional high-N inputs (blood meal) on leafy crops unless deficiency is visible.
Granular organics release more slowly; pair with fish fertilizer for quick correction.

container_refresh.rate: 10–30% of total mix when re-potting; or 1–2 inch topdress

compatibility_notes: For solid-bottom planters, ensure drainage is adequate; compost increases water-holding.

Garden_Gypsum.reference_rate_note: Espoma guidance for garden beds is 6 lb per 30 sq ft incorporated.

bed.rate: 6 lb per 30 sq ft (incorporate into top ~6 inches)

containers.rate: light application; avoid heavy dosing without knowing mix chemistry

cautions: Gypsum is not a substitute for lime; does not raise pH.
Use primarily if calcium is needed or soil structure benefits; soil test recommended.
Avoid applying in full sun heat; can cause leaf burn when foliar feeding.
Can attract animals; water in well and store securely.

beds.rate: 3 lb (9 cups) per 50 sq ft worked into top 4–6 inches

single_plant.rate: 3 Tbsp mixed into planting hole/soil at planting

pots.rate: 2 cups per cubic foot of soil (~1.5 Tbsp per quart)

feeding_schedule.frequency: twice per month during growing season

cautions: Keep at least ~3 inches from stems when top-dressing.
Do not overfertilize early; can cause excessive vegetative growth.

new_garden.rate: 2–3 lb per 100 sq ft mixed into top ~3 inches

new_transplant.rate: 1 tsp per hole mixed into soil

side_dress.rate: 1–2 tsp monthly depending on plant size and desired growth rate

cautions: Overuse increases pest pressure and reduces fruiting in tomatoes/peppers.
Can burn seedlings if concentrated; always mix thoroughly and water in.

transplant.rate: handful mixed in planting hole or 1/2–1 inch topdress

tea.rate: optional brewed tea; apply during stress periods

purpose: flowering support if soil P is low
cautions: Phosphorus persists; avoid routine use without soil test to prevent excess P.

bed_preplant.rate: follow label; common baseline 1–2 Tbsp per sq ft incorporated

planting_hole.rate: 1–2 Tbsp mixed into soil, not touching roots directly

cautions: Best used based on soil test; slow to become available.

bed_preplant.rate: follow label; often 2–5 lb per 100 sq ft

cautions: Raises soil pH; do not use on crops preferring neutral to slightly acidic soils unless pH is low.
Keep away from seedlings and do not mix with ammonium sources at same time.

bed.rate: light dusting; generally <= 5–10 lb per 1,000 sq ft

cautions: Brew and apply properly to avoid pathogen risk; use clean equipment.

LegumeInoculant.usage: Coat seed prior to sowing per label; avoid direct sun exposure and plant promptly.
cautions: Store cool/dry; inoculant viability declines with heat/time.

best_practice: Apply early morning or late evening to reduce leaf burn and protect pollinators.
Spray undersides of leaves; repeat weekly/biweekly when pressure is present.
Test on a small area first, especially in hot weather.

typical_rates.foliar_general: Follow concentrate label; common rates are ~1–2 Tbsp per gallon with a small amount of mild soap as emulsifier (if required by product).
typical_rates.soil_drench: Often 1–2 tsp per gallon for drench (label dependent).

best_practice: Use preventively or at first sign; coverage is critical.
Do not overuse; copper accumulates in soil. Rotate strategies and follow label.
compatibility: Avoid tank-mixing with oils unless label permits; risk of phytotoxicity.

weekly_routine: Check undersides of leaves for aphids/eggs.
Look for chewing damage on brassicas (cabbageworms).
Monitor for powdery mildew on cucurbits in summer.
Remove diseased leaves promptly; sanitize tools.

id_tips: White, talc-like coating on upper leaf surfaces; leaves may yellow and curl.
Often worsens with high humidity and poor airflow.
Yellow/black striped beetle on cucurbits; chewing on cotyledons/leaves; can vector bacterial wilt.
Dark brown lesions with concentric rings ('target spots'), often starting on lower leaves.
Yellowing around lesions; progresses upward in warm, wet conditions.

pre_plant_soil_amendment: Spread compost evenly across the bed and lightly incorporate into the top few inches of soil.
Apply any base fertilizer or minerals per label rates and water in to activate amendments.
Rake the surface smooth so beds are level and ready for planting.
seed_start_indoor: Fill clean trays with seed-starting mix and pre-moisten so the mix is evenly damp.
Sow seeds at the listed depth, cover lightly, and keep warm until germination.
Provide bright light immediately after germination to prevent leggy seedlings.
direct_sow: Sow into finely prepared soil, firm gently, and water with a soft spray so seed is not displaced.
Keep the seedbed evenly moist until seedlings emerge and are established.
Thin to final spacing once true leaves appear to avoid crowding.
harden_off: Start with 1–2 hours outdoors in shade and increase exposure daily for 5–7 days.
Bring seedlings in if night temps drop below crop tolerance or winds are strong.
Reduce watering slightly to help seedlings adjust without stressing them.
transplant: Plant in the late afternoon or on a cloudy day to reduce shock.
Set plants at the same depth they were in the pot unless the crop benefits from deeper planting.
Water in immediately after planting and keep soil consistently moist for the first week.
thin_seedlings: Thin by snipping at the soil line to avoid disturbing neighboring roots.
Leave the healthiest, most evenly spaced seedlings in place.
install_support: Install trellis, stakes, or netting before plants sprawl to avoid root damage later.
Secure supports firmly so they can handle wind and crop weight.
fertilize: Apply fertilizer to moist soil and water in afterward unless the product label says otherwise.
Side-dress granular products a few inches from stems; avoid direct contact with foliage.
Adjust frequency based on plant vigor and avoid over-fertilizing.
fish_fertilizer: Mix fish fertilizer with water per label and apply as a soil drench at the base of plants.
Avoid foliar contact in hot sun to reduce leaf burn.
Rinse watering cans or sprayers after use to prevent odor buildup.
tomato_tone_topdress: Sprinkle topdress evenly around the drip line and lightly scratch into the surface.
Water well to move nutrients into the root zone.
irrigation_check: Confirm emitters are flowing and adjust run times for recent weather.
Check that water reaches the root zone and is not pooling on the surface.
pest_scout: Inspect the undersides of leaves, new growth, and stems where pests hide.
Look for feeding damage, frass, and eggs in addition to live insects.
Record findings so you can track outbreaks over time.
spray: Mix product at the label dilution and cover both leaf surfaces.
Avoid spraying during peak heat or when pollinators are active unless the label allows it.
prune_train: Remove damaged or crowded foliage first to improve airflow.
Tie or train vines gently to prevent snapping stems.
harvest: Harvest in the cool of the morning for best flavor and shelf life.
Use clean tools and handle produce gently to avoid bruising.
succession_sow: Repeat sowing on the schedule to keep a steady harvest window.
Remove residue from previous successions to reduce disease carryover.
end_of_season_cleanup: Remove spent plant material and dispose of any diseased debris away from beds.
Add compost or mulch to protect soil until the next planting.
cleanup_rotate: Clear the bed, note disease or pest issues, and plan rotation to a different crop family.
Refresh soil with compost before the next crop if needed.

defaults.notes: Verify emitters working; adjust run time for temperature/rainfall.

site_requirements.container_suitability: Possible in large containers (5+ gal) but best in beds

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

fertility_strategy.dose: 1/8 cup per gallon; drench at base
1 tsp side-dress monthly only if leaves pale/slow growth

prevention: Use insect netting/row cover early to exclude cabbage moths.
Rotate brassicas 3+ years if possible to reduce soilborne disease.
Water at soil line; avoid wet foliage overnight.

succession.pattern: Spring crop then switch bed to warm-season crop; or plan fall broccoli

harvest_and_use.harvest_window: ~65–75 days from transplant; earlier for fall in cool weather
harvest_and_use.harvest_method: Cut main head when tight; leave plant for side shoots
harvest_and_use.frequency: Main head once + side shoots every 2–4 days for 2–4 weeks

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Keep evenly moist; avoid legginess.

task_plan.water_in_instructions: Water deeply; keep moist first week.

task_plan.notes: Install immediately if using.
Check undersides weekly.
Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.
Rolling: next due is based on the last time you mark this complete.

spring.notes: Broccoli prefers cool weather; spring crop can bolt in heat.

fall.notes: Fall crop is usually higher quality in DC.

soil_preparation.compost: 1–2 inches incorporated pre-plant; brassicas are heavy feeders
soil_preparation.base_fertilizer: Dr. Earth 5-5-5 at 3 Tbsp/sq ft pre-plant
soil_preparation.nitrogen_support: Blood meal 1 tsp per plant at transplant (optional) OR 1 Tbsp/sq ft for low-N beds
soil_preparation.calcium_support: Gypsum 1–2 lbs/100 sq ft if Ca is low or clubroot risk is being managed via pH strategies (soil test)
soil_preparation.notes: Primary risk is insufficient N early; keep steady growth to avoid buttoning and stress.

supplement_schedule.notes: Continue until heads/sprouts begin to form.
Avoid over-fertilizing late; prioritize moisture consistency.

site_requirements.container_suitability: Good in deep containers (10–12 in depth)

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

fertility_strategy.timing: once seedlings 2–3 true leaves; repeat every 3 weeks if growth slow

prevention: Keep foliage dry; thin for airflow.
Remove infected leaves; rotate crops.

harvest_and_use.harvest_method: Pull when 1.5–3 in diameter; twist greens off
harvest_and_use.frequency: Single harvest per sowing (can harvest greens earlier)
harvest_and_use.storage: Roots 1–3 months refrigerated in perforated bag; greens 2–4 days

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.

task_plan.stop_conditions: Stop 2 weeks before harvest if roots sized

task_plan.notes: Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.
Quick weekly inspection. If you see issues, add targeted control tasks.

planting.notes: Seed is a cluster; thinning is essential for uniform roots.

soil_preparation.compost: 0.5–1 inch incorporated; avoid fresh high-N amendments
soil_preparation.worm_castings: Light dusting in row; do not concentrate in clumps
soil_preparation.base_fertilizer: Dr. Earth 5-5-5 at 1 Tbsp/sq ft pre-plant (light)
soil_preparation.phosphorus: Bone meal/rock phosphate only if soil test indicates low P; otherwise omit
soil_preparation.potassium_note: Wood ash only if soil test indicates low K AND pH is not high; otherwise omit
soil_preparation.notes: Excess N causes hairy/forked roots and heavy tops; prioritize loose soil and consistent moisture.

supplement_schedule.notes: Use only if growth is pale/slow; otherwise skip.
Optional; do not overfeed.

plants.name: Brussels Sprouts (Marte)

site_requirements.container_suitability: Not ideal; needs large volume and stability

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

fertility_strategy.dose: 1–2 tsp side dress monthly if pale

prevention: Use netting early; scout weekly.
Remove lower yellow leaves to improve airflow if disease pressure.

support_and_training: Stake plants in windy sites; tall stalk can topple.

harvest_and_use.harvest_window: After cool weather; ~100–110 days from transplant
harvest_and_use.harvest_method: Pick firm sprouts from bottom upward; optionally top plant late season to size sprouts
harvest_and_use.storage: Refrigerate 1–2 weeks; best flavor after light frost

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Grow sturdy transplants.
Hand pick; consider netting.
Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.
Begin hardening off seedlings before transplanting.
Rolling: next due is based on the last time you mark this complete.

primary.notes: In DC, brussels are typically a fall crop transplanted mid-summer.

fall.notes: Fall crop window based on primary guidance; adjust as needed.

soil_preparation.compost: 1–2 inches incorporated pre-plant; brassicas are heavy feeders
soil_preparation.base_fertilizer: Dr. Earth 5-5-5 at 3 Tbsp/sq ft pre-plant
soil_preparation.nitrogen_support: Blood meal 1 tsp per plant at transplant (optional) OR 1 Tbsp/sq ft for low-N beds
soil_preparation.calcium_support: Gypsum 1–2 lbs/100 sq ft if Ca is low or clubroot risk is being managed via pH strategies (soil test)
soil_preparation.notes: Primary risk is insufficient N early; keep steady growth to avoid buttoning and stress.

supplement_schedule.notes: Continue until heads/sprouts begin to form.
Avoid over-fertilizing late; prioritize moisture consistency.

plants.name: Aunt Molly’s Ground Cherry

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

prevention: Mulch; water at base; remove diseased leaves.

support_and_training: Low cage or trellis helps keep fruit clean; plants sprawl.

harvest_and_use.harvest_window: ~70–80 days from transplant; continues until frost
harvest_and_use.harvest_method: Collect fallen husked fruits from ground when papery husk turns tan and fruit is yellow
harvest_and_use.storage: Room temp 3–7 days (in husk); refrigerate longer

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Bottom heat improves germination.

task_plan.water_in_instructions: Water in with fish fertilizer (half strength).

task_plan.notes: Prevents sprawl and keeps fruits cleaner.

task_plan.maturity_signs: Fruits drop; husk tan; fruit golden
task_plan.storage_notes: Keep in husk for best shelf life.

task_plan.notes: Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.
Begin hardening off seedlings before transplanting.
Rolling: next due is based on the last time you mark this complete.
Rolling: topdress cadence for flowering/fruiting; adjust if plants are overly leafy.
Quick weekly inspection. If you see issues, add targeted control tasks.

planting.notes: Warm-season; slow starter; do not transplant into cold soil.

soil_preparation.compost: 1–2 inches incorporated pre-plant; avoid burying stems in fresh compost pockets (even mixing)
soil_preparation.worm_castings: 0.5–1 cup per transplant hole or 5–10% of container mix
soil_preparation.base_fertilizer: Dr. Earth 5-5-5 at 2–3 Tbsp/sq ft worked in 1–2 weeks pre-plant
soil_preparation.calcium_support: Gypsum 1–2 lbs/100 sq ft pre-plant if soil test indicates low Ca or if blossom-end rot risk; otherwise omit
soil_preparation.phosphorus: Bone meal/rock phosphate ONLY if soil test indicates low P; otherwise avoid adding P
soil_preparation.notes: Goal: steady N early, then bias toward K/Ca during flowering/fruiting; avoid excess N once fruit set begins.

supplement_schedule.stop_conditions: Reduce/stop if plants are overly leafy or dark green; resume at lower rate.

supplement_schedule.rate: 2 Tbsp per plant (in-ground) or 1 Tbsp per 5-gal container
supplement_schedule.notes: Scratch in lightly and water. Use as primary in-season granular for tomatoes/peppers.
Use as a light booster, not a primary feed, to avoid excess vegetative growth.
Optional; prioritize consistent watering and mulch over teas if time constrained.

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

fertility_strategy.dose: small amount per label if soil test indicates low P

prevention: Thin for airflow; avoid overhead irrigation late day.

harvest_and_use.frequency: Single harvest per sowing; can pull selectively

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Remove diseased foliage early.
Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.

planting.notes: Keep surface consistently moist until germination; cover with board/burlap and mist if needed.

soil_preparation.worm_castings: Light dusting in row; do not concentrate in clumps

soil_preparation.phosphorus: Bone meal/rock phosphate only if soil test indicates low P; otherwise omit
soil_preparation.potassium_note: Wood ash only if soil test indicates low K AND pH is not high; otherwise omit

plants.name: Pumpkin Spice Jalapeño Pepper

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

fertility_strategy.dose: 1/8 cup/gal every 3 weeks if growth slows

prevention: Avoid waterlogging; ensure drainage in solid-bottom planters (add drainage holes or overflow).

support_and_training: Stake or cage if heavy fruiting or windy; prune minimal.

harvest_and_use.harvest_window: ~70–85 days from transplant; continuous until frost
harvest_and_use.harvest_method: Cut fruit with scissors; avoid tearing stems
harvest_and_use.storage: Refrigerate 1–2 weeks; freeze whole or sliced

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Heat mat recommended.

task_plan.water_in_instructions: Water in with half-strength fish fertilizer.

task_plan.notes: If mites appear, spray neem in evening; repeat weekly.
Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.
Rolling: next due is based on the last time you mark this complete.
Rolling: topdress cadence for flowering/fruiting; adjust if plants are overly leafy.

planting.notes: Peppers stall in cool soil; wait for warm nights.

plants.name: Mini Cucumber (Silor-type)

site_requirements.container_suitability: Good in 7–15 gal containers with trellis

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

prevention: Use row cover until flowering if beetles are present (remove for pollination).
Provide strong airflow (trellis) and avoid wet leaves at night.

support_and_training: Trellis strongly recommended; improves airflow and fruit quality.

harvest_and_use.harvest_method: Pick at 4–6 inches (mini types) before seeds enlarge
harvest_and_use.storage: Refrigerate 7–10 days; avoid coldest part of fridge

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Install before vines run.

task_plan.stop_conditions: Stop after vines decline or ~4 weeks before first frost

task_plan.notes: If beetles heavy, protect seedlings; if mildew begins, consider copper per label and improve airflow.

task_plan.storage_notes: Harvest often to keep plants producing.

task_plan.notes: Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.
Rolling: next due is based on the last time you mark this complete.

indoor_start_optional.notes: Start in 3–4" pots; transplant carefully young.

planting.notes: Warm soil critical; avoid cold snaps.

soil_preparation.compost: 1–2 inches incorporated pre-plant; cucurbits respond strongly to rich soil
soil_preparation.worm_castings: 0.5 cup per planting station or 5–10% container mix
soil_preparation.base_fertilizer: Dr. Earth 5-5-5 at 2–3 Tbsp/sq ft pre-plant
soil_preparation.notes: Keep soil evenly moist; avoid high N once vines set fruit to prevent excess foliage and poor fruit set.

supplement_schedule.rate: 1 Tbsp/sq ft topdress OR 1 Tbsp per 5-gal container
supplement_schedule.notes: Prefer modest topdress over frequent liquid N during fruiting.

site_requirements.container_suitability: Possible in deep trough containers with trellis; yields lower than beds

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

prevention: Good drainage; avoid waterlogged containers; trellis for airflow.

harvest_and_use.harvest_window: ~60–75 days; harvest before heat ends flowering
harvest_and_use.harvest_method: Pick pods when full and bright green; shell immediately for sweetness

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Install at sowing to avoid root damage.
If aphids present, spray strong water jet; neem as last resort on peas.

task_plan.next_crop_suggestion: Switch to cucumbers, peppers, or basil; peas finish in heat

task_plan.notes: Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.

planting.notes: Peas prefer cool weather; end production when temps rise.

soil_preparation.worm_castings: Light dusting in furrow or 0.25 cup per linear foot
soil_preparation.base_fertilizer: Dr. Earth 5-5-5 at 1–2 Tbsp/sq ft pre-plant
soil_preparation.notes: Aim for quick, steady growth; avoid large N spikes right before harvest to reduce excess nitrate accumulation concerns.

supplement_schedule.stop_conditions: Stop 7 days before harvest if desired for quality; optional.

soil_preparation.compost: 1 inch incorporated pre-plant; too-rich soil can increase pest pressure but improves yields
soil_preparation.worm_castings: Light dusting in furrow or 0.25 cup per linear foot
soil_preparation.base_fertilizer: Dr. Earth 5-5-5 at 1–2 Tbsp/sq ft pre-plant
soil_preparation.notes: Aim for quick, steady growth; avoid large N spikes right before harvest to reduce excess nitrate accumulation concerns.

supplement_schedule.stop_conditions: Stop 7 days before harvest if desired for quality; optional.

supplement_schedule.notes: Refreshes shallow-root zone for repeated cuts/succession.

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

harvest_and_use.harvest_window: ~20–35 days baby leaf; longer for mature
harvest_and_use.notes: Rustic types often have more serrated leaves and stronger flavor.

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.

plants.name: Magic Mountain Tomato

site_requirements.container_suitability: Good in 10–20 gal containers; consistent watering critical

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

fertility_strategy.dose: 3 Tbsp Tomato-tone mixed in soil + handful castings

prevention: Water consistently; avoid swings to reduce blossom-end rot.
Prune lower leaves off soil; keep foliage dry; consider copper preventively in wet spells.
Rotate nightshades if possible.

support_and_training: Use sturdy cage or stake + ties.
Prune to 1–2 leaders if indeterminate; remove suckers below first flower cluster for airflow.
Mulch heavily to stabilize moisture and reduce splash disease.

harvest_and_use.harvest_window: ~70–80 days from transplant; continues until frost
harvest_and_use.harvest_method: Pick when fully colored; allow to finish at room temp if threatened by weather
harvest_and_use.storage: Store at room temp; refrigerate only fully ripe if necessary

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Pot up to 3–4 inch pots when true leaves.
Install at transplant to avoid root damage.

task_plan.water_in_instructions: Water deeply; mulch after soil warms.

task_plan.stop_conditions: Stop after late August or when plants senesce

task_plan.notes: Increase airflow; reduce disease.
Handpick hornworms; apply copper per label at first disease signs.
Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.
Rolling: next due is based on the last time you mark this complete.
Rolling: topdress cadence for flowering/fruiting; adjust if plants are overly leafy.

planting.notes: Transplant after nights reliably >50–55°F; bury stem deeper for roots.

soil_preparation.compost: 1–2 inches incorporated pre-plant; avoid burying stems in fresh compost pockets (even mixing)
soil_preparation.worm_castings: 0.5–1 cup per transplant hole or 5–10% of container mix
soil_preparation.base_fertilizer: Dr. Earth 5-5-5 at 2–3 Tbsp/sq ft worked in 1–2 weeks pre-plant
soil_preparation.calcium_support: Gypsum 1–2 lbs/100 sq ft pre-plant if soil test indicates low Ca or if blossom-end rot risk; otherwise omit
soil_preparation.phosphorus: Bone meal/rock phosphate ONLY if soil test indicates low P; otherwise avoid adding P
soil_preparation.notes: Goal: steady N early, then bias toward K/Ca during flowering/fruiting; avoid excess N once fruit set begins.

supplement_schedule.stop_conditions: Reduce/stop if plants are overly leafy or dark green; resume at lower rate.

supplement_schedule.rate: 2 Tbsp per plant (in-ground) or 1 Tbsp per 5-gal container
supplement_schedule.notes: Scratch in lightly and water. Use as primary in-season granular for tomatoes/peppers.
Use as a light booster, not a primary feed, to avoid excess vegetative growth.
Optional; prioritize consistent watering and mulch over teas if time constrained.

fertility_strategy.dose: 1 inch compost or handful castings per clump

harvest_and_use.harvest_window: Begin light harvest once leaves are 8–10 inches; multiple harvests
harvest_and_use.harvest_method: Cut leaves 1–2 inches above soil; allow regrowth

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.

task_plan.storage_notes: Do not cut all leaves on young plants first year.

indoor_start_optional.notes: Slow from seed; many growers transplant.

planting.notes: Perennial; establish first year, heavier harvest later.

soil_preparation.compost: 0.5–1 inch incorporated; herbs often prefer leaner soil
soil_preparation.base_fertilizer: Optional: Dr. Earth 5-5-5 at 0.5–1 Tbsp/sq ft if soil is poor
soil_preparation.notes: Over-fertilizing reduces flavor intensity in many herbs.

supplement_schedule.frequency: Once in spring if weak growth
supplement_schedule.notes: Otherwise rely on compost only.

watering.general: Aim for ~1–1.5 inches/week total (rain+irrigation) for most vegetables; more in containers and heat.
watering.irrigation_notes: Drip irrigation preferred; water early to reduce disease.

prevention: Avoid overwatering; ensure drainage and airflow.

harvest_and_use.harvest_window: Light harvest first year once established; perennial/woody
harvest_and_use.harvest_method: Snip sprigs; avoid cutting into old woody stems excessively
harvest_and_use.frequency: As needed; best flavor before flowering
harvest_and_use.storage: Dry or freeze; refrigerate fresh 7–10 days

task_plan.notes: Apply compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Surface sow; mist; do not cover heavily.

task_plan.water_in_instructions: Water in; then allow surface to dry slightly between waterings.

task_plan.storage_notes: Harvest before flowering for peak aroma.

task_plan.notes: Remove crop residues; discard diseased material; leave roots of legumes if applicable; prep space for fall/winter rotation.

planting.notes: Thyme seed is tiny; surface sow and press in; keep misted.

soil_preparation.compost: 0.5–1 inch incorporated; herbs often prefer leaner soil
soil_preparation.base_fertilizer: Optional: Dr. Earth 5-5-5 at 0.5–1 Tbsp/sq ft if soil is poor
soil_preparation.notes: Over-fertilizing reduces flavor intensity in many herbs.

supplement_schedule.frequency: Once in spring if weak growth
supplement_schedule.notes: Otherwise rely on compost only.

cool_season_spring.notes: Use row covers for warmth and pest exclusion; plan succession sowing every 10–21 days.

warm_season_summer.notes: Mulch heavily; monitor irrigation; start disease prevention early in humid stretches.

cool_season_fall.notes: Fall is prime for brassicas and greens in DC; use netting for caterpillars/harlequin bugs.

actions: Consider cover crop or mulch beds

compost.purpose: Organic matter, slow nutrients, microbial life
compost.notes: Foundation amendment for all beds and containers

worm_castings.rate: 5–10% of soil volume or 0.5–1 cup per transplant hole

dr_earth_5_5_5.rate: 2–3 Tbsp per sq ft (beds); 1–2 Tbsp per gallon (containers)
dr_earth_5_5_5.frequency: At planting; reapply every 4–6 weeks if needed

tomato_tone_3_4_6.rate: 2 Tbsp per plant or 3–4 Tbsp per sq ft

wood_ash.caution: Avoid if soil pH is high

global_tasks.notes: Full soil test including pH and lead.
Incorporate compost, worm castings, and base fertilizer.
Plan fall successions (greens, brassicas, roots). Clear space by pulling bolting/declining crops; start transplants where needed.
Topdress 0.5–1 inch compost; lightly work in; refresh container media (remove 20–30% and replace with compost + new mix).
Decide: sow a cover crop (e.g., winter rye + clover) OR apply 2–4 inches mulch/leaves for winter soil protection.
After beds are cleared, apply 2–4 inches leaf mulch or straw; protect soil and suppress winter weeds; leave in place until spring.
Optional: soil test post-season to plan lime/sulfur and nutrient strategy for next year.

fall_reconditioning_notes: Prioritize compost topdressing and residue removal to reduce disease carryover.
If you experienced significant disease (e.g., tomato blight), remove all debris and consider longer rotations in that bed/planter.
Cover crops are optional but beneficial for erosion control and organic matter; mulch is a simpler alternative in small beds/containers.
Avoid adding high-phosphorus amendments unless soil test indicates deficiency.
